bibl.title: Notes from Review of Applied Entomology, by [Henry Rose Carter?], [19--]

div1.head: Notes from Review of Applied Entomology, by [Henry Rose Carter?], [19--]
div1.p:
The following are notes from the Review of Applied Entomology of the
dates given. I have not had, and will not have, time to look up the original
sources, which are noted, however, in the notes.

R. A. E. April 1920:/ Bol. Royal Sec. Espanola Historia Natural, Madrid
XIX: No. 8: Oct. 1919:--

Larvae of S.tegomyia culex and Anopheles,. never found in pools (or tanks) containing
a certain amount of Chara foetida. Quantity necessary to cause death
not determined. In 50 c. c. of water, mass of vegetation must occupy
somewhat more than 1/8 of the space--less than this will prevent ovi-
position and kill some and hinder greatly the developement of the others.
Larvae of Stegomyia appear to be slightly more resistant than the others.
Chara foetida is easy to grow, both in town and country.

The cause of the toxicity to which this plant gives rise clearly
lies in the fact that, if left uncovered, the surfaces of any water con-
taining the growing plant quickly become covered with patches of a thin
oily substance and this, within 3 or 4 days, forms a light film deepen-
ing later to about 1/2 m. m. in thickness. It is evident that this film
interferes with the respiration of the larvae.

Bulletin Royal Society Espanola Historia Natural, Madrid: XXII:
No. 1-2: Jan. & Feb. 1921 (P. 61-64):--

The toxic principle (to mosquito larvae) is (1) nst soluble in
water: (2) not accumulated in the living cells of the alga, but present
in water in which Chara foetida has lived. Hence a secretion of the
plant. Waters in which Chara spec. have lived are as potent a larvacide
as the plant itself. In surveys about the mouth of the river, Llobre-
gat 300 collections of water: pools: canals: drains etc. in which
Chara spec. are present, no larvae of Anopheles or Culex: in all other
where no Chara: larvae+++.

Copy sent-
to Fricks with Mem.
Barber
Arthur Georgetown
Williams L.L.
Griffitts

Three species of Chara--foetida: contraria and hispida--possess the
power of destroying mosquito larvae. Anales: Ins't. General y Tec-
nico de Valencia: #10: P. 5-17. (Ab. T. D. Bull: London, Feb. 1922, P. 113)

Stegomyia larvae died almost immediately on hatching, although there
was no film on the water. Controls lived. (Rice crop considered. Rice
and Chara grow well together.)
